#Text=Sharjah
#Text=Sharjah ( Arabic : الشارقة ) is the third largest city in the United Arab Emirates and the capital of Sharjah emirate .
#Text=Sharjah is known for its Arabic and Islamic architecture as well as its libraries , Islamic museums , and cultural centers .
#Text=The city is known as the cultural and literature hub of the United Arab Emirates .

#Text=The city is rooted in its Arabic and Islamic heritage with many Ummayyad and Abbasid-styled buildings and offers a glimpse of Arabic and Islamic environment in an otherwise largely westernized country .
#Text=It is a major hub for family friendly environment and activities and has a more conservative atmosphere .

#Text=The city has many green parks , apartment complexes , and a large community of Arabs from all the Arab world making the city an effective cultural meeting point for many different communities of Arabs .
#Text=In contrast to Abu Dhabi and Dubai , Sharjah offers visitors a vastly larger view into Arabic and Islamic art , literature , and architecture .
#Text=It s a usual destination for visitors who are looking for a cultural and a more local experience of Arabia and Islamic atmosphere compared to Abu Dhabi and Dubai .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Sharjah is very closely connected to Dubai through the Dubai-Sharjah-Ajman metropolitan area , with commuter traffic creating rush hour traffic jams .
#Text=Many people live in Sharjah but work in Dubai , hence traffic from Sharjah to Dubai and Dubai to Sharjah is largely expected in rush hours .
#Text=The emirate is considerably larger than Dubai , with coastline on both west and east coasts of the peninsula , and with exclaves of Kalba , Khor Fakkan , and Dibba Al Hisn .
#Text=The road to the east coast goes through rugged Al Hajar mountains .
#Text=Public buildings in the Emirate are all in Umayyad and Abbasid architecture , and were all designed by the present Shaikh ( a qualified architect ) .
#Text=Therefore the city offers a nice visual change and a more cultural atmosphere from the usual fare of skyscrapers in other Emirates .
#Text=The Sharjah Commerce and Tourism website has sections on business , heritage , leisure , education , and coast .
#Text=Talk
#Text=As in the rest of the UAE , Arabic is the official language , although most residents speak other languages - particularly Hindi , Urdu and Tagalog .
#Text=English is widely spoken in shops , souqs , and hotels .
#Text=Get in
#Text=For visa requirements to visit Sharjah , see the United Arab Emirates page .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Sharjah International Airport ( SHJ ) ( is around 15 kilometres from Sharjah city ) .
#Text=It is the home of the low-cost carrier Air Arabia which has connections with various Middle East and Indian Subcontinent cities .
#Text=Getting to/from the airport :
#Text=There is a shuttle bus connecting the airport with Sharjah centre ( Rolla ) running every 30 min ( 5 dirham ) .
#Text=Public bus route 111 ( 10 dirham ) runs hourly from the airport via Al Qusais Bus station to the Metro 's Rashidiya station in Dubai .
#Text=Dubai International Airport ( DXB ) , in the neighbouring emirate of Dubai , has many more international connections and will be the more popular gateway to Sharjah .
#Text=Getting to/from the airport :
#Text=To go to Dubai International Airport by taxi will set you back at around 100 dirham .
#Text=You can travel by public bus to or from Dubai International Airport by using Dubai 's local bus service and the inter-Emirate bus service .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Bus travel to Dubai is possible via an inter-emirate bus service run by the Government of Dubai Road and Transport Authority .
#Text=Most buses arrive at , next to the Sharjah Fish market and the Sharjah Fruit and Vegetable market , nearby to the Central Souk .
#Text=A bus from Sharjah to Dubai can take about 1 hr and costs 5 dirham .
#Text=Timetables can be found at the RTA website .
#Text=By taxi
#Text=Taxis are widely available .
#Text=Taxis can travel from other emirates such as from Dubai to Sharjah or from Ajman to Sharjah and vice versa without any restrictions .
#Text=Traveling from farther emirates such as Abu Dhabi or Ras Al Khaimah is also an option , but taxi fares may be costly .
#Text=Ride-share applications such as Uber and Careem are also an option and can be used to travel across emirates .
#Text=You may also call the government sponsored Sharjah taxi service to request a taxis to come right to your location .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Public buses are by Sharjah Transport , There are seven local and three express routes .
#Text=Dubai 's RTA also offers express commuter bus service .
#Text=Licensed taxi companies are Sharjah , Emirates , Citi , Union , and Advantage .
#Text=Taxi plates are reflective green , which helps to spot them at night .
#Text=Flag fall is 3.50 dirham , then 1 dirham every 650 m , and the minimum fare is 11.50 dirham .
#Text=There is a surcharge of 20 dirham to go into Dubai .
#Text=See
#Text=Heritage Area - Good overview available here including a few restoration of old houses .
#Text=The Heritage is situated near the Corniche between Burj Avenue & Al-Maraija Road .
#Text=Many historic buildings have been reconstructed with traditional materials .
#Text=The most interesting sites are Al Hisn Fort , Literature Square with House of Poetry , Sharjah Museum of Islamic Civilization , Sharjah Heritage Museum and Souq al-Arsa .
#Text=Most sites in the Heritage Area have opening times set aside solely for women .
#Text=Visitors of both genders should make certain of these on arrival in the city .
#Text=Al Hisn Fort , Al-Hosn Avenue , ☏ +97165685500 .
#Text=Sa - Th 8AM-2PM , F closed .
#Text=The Sharjah Fort Museum dominates the Heritage District .
#Text=The fort itself has been lovingly restored by the present Sheikh and the museum provides something of a glimpse at social history of the Emirate .
#Text=Many exhibit signs , however , are solely in Arabic , with those in English often being rife with errors .
#Text=Adult 5 dirham , family 10 dirham , children free .
#Text=Sharjah Museum of Islamic Civilization , ☏ +97165655455 .
#Text=Sa - Th 8AM-8PM , F 4-8PM .

#Text=Sharjah Museum of Islamic Civilization is a fascinating place for any visitors with an interest in the faith , as there are handwritten Qur'ans , letters from the Prophet Muhammad to other leaders and various artifacts from Mecca .
#Text=Also a comprehensive display of Arab handicrafts .
#Text=Adult 5 dirham , family 10 dirham , children free .
#Text=Bait al-Naboodah , Heritage Area , ☏ +97165685500 .
#Text=Sa - Th 8AM-8PM , F 4-8PM .
#Text=Adult 5 dirham , family 10 dirham , children free .
#Text=Souq al-Arsah , Heritage Area .
#Text=Sa - Th 9AM-1PM , 4-9PM , F 4-9PM only .
#Text=Another souq worth a visit .
#Text=It is considered to be the oldest souq in the country .
#Text=Stop at the traditional coffehouse for a mint tea and a plate of dates .
#Text=Sharjah Calligraphy Museum ( Heritage Area ) , ☏ +97165694561 .
#Text=Sa - Th 8AM-8PM , F 4-8PM .

#Text=A small museum with magnificent calligraphic works of art by Persian , Arabic and Turkish artists with a workshop where students are trained in the art of calligraphy Adult 5 dirham , family 10 dirham , children free .
#Text=Sharjah Heritage Museum ( Heritage Area ) , ☏ +97165680006 .
#Text=Sa - Th 8AM-8PM , F 4-8PM .
#Text=A small museum about the history and habits of the emirate Adult 10 dirham , children 5 dirham .
#Text=Art Area - Includes Sharjah 's Art Museum which covers regional and international art exhibits , with the oriental collection being its highlights .
#Text=The Arts Area is situated opposite the Heritage Area on the other side of Burj Avenue .
#Text=Sharjah Art Museum , ☏ +97165688222 .
#Text=Sa - Th 8AM-8PM , F 4-8PM .
#Text=The Sharjah Art Museum shows contemporary art by local and foreign artists .
#Text=It is also the home of the Sharjah International Art Biennale , a bi-yearly exhibition of international contemporary art and performance .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Sharjah Archeology Museum , Sheikh Rashid bin Saqr alQassimi Rd , ☏ +97165665466 .
#Text=Sa - Th 9AM-1PM , 5-8PM ; F 5-8PM .

#Text=The museum explore the changing environments experienced by the region 's inhabitants from the Stone Age to the present day through displays of artefacts , coins , jewellery , pottery and ancient weapons .
#Text=Investigate a dig in progress , explore models of burials , houses and tombs and see the first forms of writing in this area .
#Text=Adult 10 dirham , children 5 dirham .
#Text=Other museums also covers marine , natural history , aviation , and other valuable aspects http://www.sharjahmuseums.ae/.
#Text=Blue Souq ( Souq Al Markazi or Central Souq ) . An interesting , if slightly chaotic , shopping centre hosting around 600 shops in two wings .
#Text=The ground floor shops tend to stock gold and expensive designer clothes , with the upper level containing shops stocking carpets and curios from as far afield as Afghanistan and Tibet .
#Text=Haggling over prices in the upper-level shops will frequently attract massive discounts .
#Text=A great place to buy gifts and traditional goods .
#Text=Considered superior to Dubai for carpets by Western expatriates .
#Text=Sharjah Desert Park ( 28 km from Sharjah on the road to Al Dhaid ) . Su - Th 9AM – 5:30PM , F 2PM-5:30PM , Sa 11AM – 5:30PM .
#Text=It has three components spread over 1 km ² : the Natural History Museum , Arabian Wildlife Centre and the Children ’s Farm .

#Text=The museum provides people of all ages with an opportunity to learn about the flora and fauna of the Arabian Desert and has five main exhibition halls : A Journey through Sharjah , Man and the Environment , A Journey through Time , The Living Desert and The Living Sea .
#Text=The Arabian Wildlife Centre showcases the rich diversity of fauna in the Arabian Peninsula as well as teaching about species which have become , and are becoming , extinct .
#Text=It contains more than 100 species of animals , and is divided into a reptile and insect house , aviary , nocturnal houses , viewing area and a section for large predators and monkeys .
#Text=The children ’s farm gives children a chance to come into close contact with farm animals , such as donkeys , goats , sheep and chickens .
#Text=Adult 15 dirham , child ( 12 – 16 years ) 5 dirham , child ( under 12 ) free .
#Text=Fish Market , Corniche Road ( opposite Blue Suq ) .
#Text=Daily 5AM-1PM .
#Text=King Faisal Mosque , Al-Ittahid Square .
#Text=This magnificent mosque was a gift of the Saudi Arabian King Faisal .
#Text=It was opened in 1987 and has space for 15,000 people .
#Text=There are separate prayer rooms for men and women and the mosque has an Islamic library with more than 7,000 books .
#Text=Admission for Muslims only .
#Text=Al-Qasba Waterfront and Eye of the Emirates , Al-Taiwoon Road , Al-Khan Lagoon , ☏ +97165560777 .
#Text=Sa - Th 10AM-11PM , F 4-11PM .
#Text=Here you can enjoy culture , entertainment and leisure attractions representing the very best from the Arab world and beyond .
#Text=Al-Mahattah-Museum , Estiqlal Square , ☏ +97165733079 .
#Text=Sa - Th 8AM-8PM , F 4-8PM .
#Text=Al Mahatta was the first airport in the Gulf region .
#Text=It opened in 1932 as a staging post for commercial flights from Britain to India .
#Text=There is an interesting film about the daily life at the airport and Sharjah town in the 1930s and four original propeller planes stand in the hangar .
#Text=Adult 5 dirham , family 10 dirham , child free .
#Text=Sharjah Aquarium , Al Meena Street , Al Khan Area , Near Sharjah Maritime Museum , ☏ +97165285288 .
#Text=The Sharjah Aquarium first opened its doors on June 16 , 2008 .
#Text=It features deep-sea creatures .
#Text=Sharjah Maritime Museum gives you a close-up look at the local fishes and lets you learn about Sharjah 's historic coasts and ports .
#Text=35AED per adult ( Age 13+ yrs ) , 25AED per child ( age 2-12 yrs ) , below 2 yrs free . 90 AED Family ( 2 Adults + 3 Children ) .
